chapters.title: Reading Comprehension
chapters.content:
Reading comprehension is the ability to process text, understand its meaning, and to integrate with what the reader already knows. It involves active and purposeful reading to extract information and draw conclusions.

Passage 1: Life in Deserts

As what geographers have estimated, about twenty percent of the earth's surface is occupied by deserts. A majority of us view deserts as one unique kind of landscape -- areas with little or no rainfall.

In actual fact, there are differences between the deserts in varying degrees. While it is common for laymen like us to see deserts as rocky or covered with pebbles, there are some where large sand dunes inhabit. Despite the fact that rainfall is minimal, temperatures do change in deserts, ranging from seasonal ones to daily changes where extreme hotness and coldness are experienced in the day and night.

Adverse conditions in the deserts, especially the lack of water, have discouraged many living things from inhabiting these landscapes. Nevertheless, there are exceptionally surviving ones which through their superb tactics, have managed to live through and are still going strong. One such kind is the specialist annual plants which overcome seasonal temperature changes with their extremely short, active life cycles. In events of sudden rain, the plant seeds pullulate and grow very quickly to make full use of the rain water. Their flowers bloom and set seeds that ripen promptly in the hot sun too. Once the water runs dry, the mother plant dies, leaving behind the drought-resistant seeds, waiting patiently for the next rainy season to arrive.

Besides plants, there are also animals with divergent surviving tactics in deserts too. For instance, Skinks ( desert lizards ) metabolize stored fats in their bulbous tails, producing water to supplement their needs, just like what camels do with the stored food in their humps during long journeys through deserts. Antelopes like the addax, have very low water needs and hence are able to endure the conditions in deserts, extracting moisture from the food they eat.

Finally, there are the Sandgrouses (desert birds) which do not have special features to overcome the drought-like nature in deserts. To survive in these hot, dry deserts, they need to spend a large part of their time flying in search of waterholes. The truth is deserts are full of countless unique, resilient life forms.

  2. Describe two features of deserts’ weather condition.
  3. How desert plants multiply in number?
  4. How do desert lizards survive in scarcity of water?

I. General people think of deserts as rocky or pebble-covered areas with little to no rain.
II. Deserts experience extreme temperature changes, both seasonally and daily (hot days, cold nights).
III. Desert plants multiply quickly after sudden rain, using the water to grow, bloom, and set drought-resistant seeds before drying up.
IV. Desert lizards metabolize stored fat in their tails to produce water.
V. Sandgrouses spend most of their daytime flying in search of waterholes to survive.

Passage 2: Are Literate Women Better Mothers?

Children in developing countries are healthier and more likely to survive past the age of five when their mothers can read and write. Experts in public health accepted this idea decades ago, but until now no one has been able to show that a woman's ability to read in itself improves her children’s chances of survival.

Most literate women learnt to read in primary school, and the fact that a woman has had an education may simply indicate her family’s wealth or that it values its children more highly. Now a long-term study carried out in Nicaragua has eliminated these factors by showing that teaching reading to poor adult women, who would otherwise have remained illiterate, has a direct effect on their children’s health and survival.

In 1979, the government of Nicaragua established a number of social programmes, including a National Literacy Crusade (NLC). By 1985, about 300,000 illiterate adults from all over the country, many of whom had never attended primary school, had learnt how to read, write, and use numbers.

During this period, researchers interviewed nearly 3,000 women, some of whom had learnt to read as children, some during the literacy crusade and some who had never learnt at all. The women were asked how many children they had given birth to and how many of them had died in infancy. The research teams also examined the surviving children to find out how well-nourished they were.

The Investigators' findings were striking. In the late 1970s, the infant mortality rate for the children of illiterate mothers was around 110 deaths per thousand live births. For women educated in primary school, however, the infant mortality rate was significantly lower, at 80 per thousand.

In 1985, after the NLC had ended, the infant mortality figures for those who remained illiterate and for those educated in primary school remained more or less unchanged. For those women who learnt to read through the campaign, the infant mortality rate was 84 per thousand, an impressive 21 points lower than for those women who were still illiterate. The children of the newly-literate mothers were also better nourished than those of women who could not read.

b. It took 6 years (from 1979 to 1985) for the NLC to literate nearly 3 lac adults.
c. The prime target attendees were illiterate adults, many of whom had never attended primary school.
d. In the late 1970s, the infant mortality rate for mothers educated in their early ages was 80 per thousand.
e. The infant mortality rate for children of women who learned to read through the NLC dropped to 84 per thousand, which was significantly lower than that for women who remained illiterate (around 110 per thousand).

Passage 3: Ecosystem

The concept of the ecosystem has evolved since its origin. The term, coined in the 1930s, belongs to British botanists Roy Clapham and Sir Arthur Tansley. An ecosystem is a community of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment, interacting as a system. Non-living things that support life in an ecosystem are light, air, soil and water. Living things are the plants and animals, called organisms, which use those resources.

Ecosystems are controlled by external and internal factors. These conditions determine what kinds of living things will be able to thrive there. Organisms can only thrive where their needs are being met. One ecosystem that allows many different kinds of organisms to thrive is a temperate zone. It is an area where the conditions never become too hot or too cold.

All the living things in an ecosystem are called a community. All of one specific kind of organism living in a community is called a population. All living organisms perform certain life processes. They take in nutrients, use energy to grow, release waste, react to their environment, and reproduce.

Exercise Questions for Passage 3

1. Choose the correct answer.

  • a) As used in the first paragraph, the word conjunction does not mean- i) combination ii) union iii) regular
  • b) The word determine in the second paragraph means - i) decide ii) detrimental iii) destruct
  • c) The word thrive in the second paragraph means- i) decline ii) grow iii) wither
  • d) The word community in the third paragraph does not mean- i) population ii) organisms iii) society
  • e) The word organism in the fourth paragraph means- i) human being ii) organic iii) life form

2. Answer the following questions:

  1. How does an ecosystem sustain?
  2. How is the overall organization of an ecosystem controlled?
  3. Why does a temperate zone support many varieties of organisms?
  4. What does population mean in a community?
  5. What are three of the life processes that living organisms do?

1. Correct Answer:
a) iii) regular
b) i) decide
c) ii) grow
d) iii) society
e) iii) life form

2. Short Answers:
a) An ecosystem sustains by the interaction between living organisms and the nonliving components of their environment (light, air, soil, water).
b) The overall organization is controlled by external factors like climate and internal factors created by the organisms themselves.
c) A temperate zone supports many organisms because its conditions never become too hot or too cold.
d) A population is all of one specific kind of organism living in a community.
e) Three life processes are: taking in nutrients, using energy to grow and develop, and reproducing.

Passage 4: Facebook Addiction Disorder

Facebook is one of the trendiest social networking websites on the planet. Created by Harvard genius Mark Zuckerberg in 2004, it started out as a campus thing but progressively became a worldwide source of communication and entertainment. Many teens have admitted that they are unquestionably addicted to Facebook. This Facebook fever is so strong that even educated business people to intrigued grandparents has joined the phenomenon.

No doubt Facebook is a stroke of genius but excess of everything is bad. Facebook is taking over the world and that is no exaggeration. That can easily be seen by the fact that people spend more time on Facebook than actually being involved in any other activity. This is called F.A.D: Facebook Addiction Disorder.

A person suffering from F.A.D spends all the time on his computer checking his notifications, messages and friend requests after every 5 minutes. Sometimes he becomes fretful just because he has not checked his account in an over an hour. That person withdraws himself from normal activities like hanging out with friends, helping around the house, going out on weekends, and eschews the rest of the world. For him Facebook is his new world.

Curing it is not easy unless we have the will power to do it. Like all other addictions, F.A.D cannot be cured overnight but if we take a healthy look at our lifestyles then we might be able to tell what went off beam with us. A balanced life is a healthy life, now it is up to us how we want to live it.

1. Choose the correct answer.

  • a) The word eschew used in the fourth paragraph means- i) being interested ii) noticing something iii) deliberately avoiding something iv) taking care
  • b) The word unquestionably used in the first paragraph means- i) without any doubt ii) with explanation iii) without logic iv) with a scope of argument
  • c) The word fretful in third paragraph does not mean- i) relaxed ii) irritated iii) uneasy iv) distressed
  • d) The word exaggeration in the second paragraph is related to the idea of- i) simplifying something ii) understanding something iii) dramatizing something excessively iv) reacting to something
  • e) The word intrigued in the first paragraph means- i) not excited ii) enthusiastic iii)uninterested iv) bored

2. Answer the following questions:

  2. Why social networking is everything for the youth of the 21st century?
  3. What are the symptoms of a person suffering from Facebook Addiction Disorder (F.A.D)?
  4. Do you think Facebook addiction is harmful like any other addiction? Give reason for your answer.
  5. How would you deal with Facebook addiction in your life?

1. Correct Answer:
a) iii) deliberately avoiding something
b) i) without any doubt
c) i) relaxed
d) iii) dramatizing something excessively
e) i) not excited (Note: The PDF seems to have a mistake here, as 'intrigued' means 'aroused the curiosity or interest of'. The provided 'correct' answer 'not excited' is an antonym. Based on context, the grandparents became interested.)

2. Short Answers:
a) Mark Zuckerberg created Facebook in 2004.
b) It allows them to stay connected to friends and family.
c) Symptoms include constantly checking notifications, becoming fretful when unable to check, and withdrawing from normal activities.
d) Yes, the passage claims it is harmful because it affects grades, homework, and life by causing withdrawal from the real world.
e) The passage suggests dealing with it requires will power and taking a healthy look at one's lifestyle.

Passage 5: A Successful Formula

Vygotsky, a Soviet educational psychologist, describes learning as a social process. According to this concept, learning takes place first at the social level through interactions with others. Another aspect of his theory is the idea that the learners are mentally prepared to a certain level and they require support from a teacher or more experienced peers in order to fully develop.

Teachers need to plan activities using cooperative learning so that learners can be meaningfully engaged. Student engagement is the fundamental component of successful academic achievement. It should be the goal of a teacher to create a congenial classroom environment where students have the freedom to contribute and debate their ideas. If teachers are highly engaging and set clear expectations, students will feel as if they belong in the classroom.

For a highly functional classroom, high-quality peer support is also important. Two heads are always better than one. When students have the opportunity to interact with each other and share learning experiences, they don't rely on rote learning.

However, it is not an easy task to bridge practical classroom application with pedagogical theory. It requires skill to engage students with a variety of activities in order to develop their abilities in critical thinking, quantitative reasoning, problem-solving and communication. The institutions should offer good quality and sustainable Continuous Professional Development (CPD) programmes. The basic principle behind this is that a good teacher should never stop being a learner.

Exercise Questions for Passage 5

1. Answer the questions in a complete sentence

  1. How does learning take place at the social level?
  2. Why is cooperative learning necessary?
  3. Why is it important to create a congenial classroom?
  4. What are the benefits of team work?
  5. What are the characteristics of experienced faculty members?

2. From the passage, find out the synonyms of the words

a. conversation b. pleasant c. related to teaching d. suggestions e. new idea

1. Short Answers:
a) Learning takes place at the social level through interactions with others.
b) Cooperative learning is necessary so that learners can be meaningfully engaged and strengthen interpersonal skills.
c) It's important to create a congenial classroom so students feel free to contribute, debate, and participate in activities.
d) Benefits of teamwork include combining ideas, giving and receiving feedback, developing deeper understanding, and not relying on rote learning.
e) They are not scared of challenges and are skilled in engaging students to develop abilities like critical thinking and problem-solving.

2. Synonyms:
a. conversation: interaction
b. pleasant: congenial
c. related to teaching: pedagogical
d. suggestions: implications
e. new idea: innovation

Passage 6: The Changing Global Diet

For several reasons, many people choose fast food. First, it is quick and convenient. Second, it is cheaper than special home-cooked meals or formal restaurant dinners. And third, it is identical in every eating place with the same company name. The main reason others dislike it is its low nutritional value. In contrast, most types of fast food have a lot of fat, cholesterol, sugar, or salt in them. Possibly, these substances can cause or increase health disorders.

Some people believe food should be perfectly fresh and "natural." They don't believe convenience foods--canned, frozen, or packaged--are very nutritious either. On the other hand, these quick and easy kinds of worldwide nourishment are generally getting better and more healthful. For instance, many fast-food restaurants now have salad bars and put vegetable items on their menus. And nutrition bars are becoming more widely available.

Of course, human beings around the world don't always eat in fast-food places. Many families prepare good meals at home. Cooking customs, eating habits, and food preferences all over the world are becoming more healthful. In these and other ways, the global diet is changing.

(a) It is quick, cheap, and identical everywhere.
(b) Because of its low nutritional value (low in fiber, vitamins, minerals and high in fat, cholesterol, sugar, salt).
(c) Protein, carbohydrates, and fats.

2. Correct Meaning:

ii) Convenience = (ii) suitability
iii) In contrast = (i) as opposed with
iv) Nourishment = (iii) healthfulness

Passage 7: Galileo

Galileo Galilei was born in the year 1564 in the town of Pisa, Italy. His father wanted him to be a doctor, but Galileo was bored with school except for math. Because math was the one subject where he was doing well, the court mathematician offered to tutor him privately. Galileo’s father was disappointed, but he agreed.

As he needed to earn money, Galileo began experimenting with different things. He had already experimented with pendulums, thermometers, and magnets. When he heard that a Dutch inventor had invented something called a spyglass, but was keeping it a secret, Galileo decided to work on one of his own. Within 24 hours, he had invented a telescope that could magnify things to make them appear ten times larger than real life. One night, he pointed his telescope toward the sky, and made his first of many space observations: the moon was not smooth, like everyone thought. The moon was covered in bumps and craters.

As technology has improved, first Galileo, and then many others, have made improvements on the telescope, the wonderful device that allows us to see from a distance.

1. Answer to the following short questions from the text:

  • b) The word ‘craters’ is the synonym of - i) holes, ii) solid, iii) compact.

1. Short Answers:
a) Galileo was born in Pisa, Italy.
b) His favorite subject was math.
c) His first successful invention mentioned was a compass-like device to measure plots of land.
d) Other inventions included pendulums, thermometers, magnets, and the telescope.
e) The telescope's features are that it can magnify things to make them appear larger than real life, allowing us to see from a distance.

2. Best Answer:
a) The word ‘except’ means- i) apart from
b) The word ‘craters’ is the synonym of - i) holes
c) The word ‘magnify’ means - iii) expand
d) The word ‘appear’ is the antonym of - i) conceal
e) The word ‘disappointed’ does not mean- i) comforted

Passage 8: The Mother’s Day

The idea of Mother’s Day is a very old idea, dating back to the ancient Egyptians and Greeks. Later, English Christians expanded the celebration to honor all mothers. This English holiday was called “Mothering Sunday.”

During the U.S. Civil War, mothers on both sides of the war lost sons. Grieving mothers from both sides had meetings. In 1868, Ann Reeves Jarvis started a committee to establish a “Mothers’ Friendship Day”. Julia Ward Howe also declared the first official Mother’s Day in 1870 and held an anti–war observance. She funded this observance with her own money for several years.

In 1914, the U.S. Congress passed a law which designated the second Sunday in May as Mother’s Day. Now the day has become commercialized, with companies launching women’s products and restaurants advertising heavily.

  2. What did Ann Reeves Jarvis do for mothers after U.S. Civil War?

1. Appropriate Option:

2. Short Answers:

b) She started a committee to help families get back together and established "Mothers' Friendship Day."
c) Julia Ward Howe declared the first official Mother's Day as an anti-war observance.
d) It was officially started in 1914 in the U.S. and is now celebrated on the same day in many other countries.
e) Yes, one can agree it has become commercialized because companies heavily advertise and launch products specifically for the day, shifting the focus to buying gifts.

chapters.title: How to Write a Paragraph
chapters.content:
What is a paragraph?

Paragraphs are comprised of sentences, but not random sentences. A paragraph is a group of sentences organized around a central topic. In fact, the basic rule of paragraph writing is to focus on one idea. A solidly written paragraph takes its readers on a clear path, without detours.

Qualities of a good paragraph

A basic paragraph structure usually consists of five sentences: the topic sentence, few supporting sentences, and a concluding sentence. But the secrets to paragraph writing lay in four essential elements, which when used correctly, can make an okay paragraph into a great paragraph.

  1. Element #1: Unity. Unity in a paragraph begins with the topic sentence. Every paragraph has one single, controlling idea that is expressed in its topic sentence, which is typically the first sentence of the paragraph. A paragraph is unified around this main idea, with the supporting sentences providing detail and discussion.
  2. Element #2: Order. Order refers to the way you organize your supporting sentences. Whether you choose chronological order, order of importance, or another logical presentation of detail, a solid paragraph always has a definite organization. Order helps the reader grasp your meaning and avoid confusion.
  3. Element #3: Coherence. Coherence is the quality that makes your writing understandable. Sentences within a paragraph need to connect to each other and work together as a whole. One of the best ways to achieve coherency is to use transition words. These words create bridges from one sentence to the next.
  4. Element #4: Completeness. Completeness means a paragraph is well-developed. If all sentences clearly and sufficiently support the main idea, then your paragraph is complete. Usually three supporting sentences, in addition to a topic sentence and concluding sentence, are needed for a paragraph to be complete.

Transitional Words

Paragraph writing: A Step-by-Step Process

  1. Decide the Topic of Your Paragraph and prepare an outline: Know what you are writing about. Note key terms from the prompt.
  2. Develop a Topic Sentence: This sentence should state the main topic and a controlling idea. For example: "People can avoid plagiarizing (topic) by taking certain precautions (controlling idea)."
  3. Demonstrate Your Point: Provide information to prove, illustrate, clarify, and/or exemplify your point using facts, details, examples, and quotations.
  4. Give Your Paragraph Meaning: Explain why the information you provided is relevant, meaningful, or interesting.
  5. Conclude: Add a concluding sentence that summarizes your points and reinforces the topic sentence. Use linking words like 'therefore' or 'thus'.
  6. Look Over and Proofread: Always revise your work. Read it out loud to check for sense and flow.

chapters.title: Descriptive Paragraph
chapters.content:
A descriptive paragraph paints a picture with words. It uses sensory details to describe a person, place, or object, allowing the reader to experience it vividly.

Techniques of describing a place

  1. Start by describing the first thing that strikes you.
  2. Highlight small details to make your description interesting.
  3. Use surprising, exotic language to make the place come to life.
  4. Write about how you react to the place.
  5. Include only the most important details so you don’t bog your reader down.
  6. Consider all five senses: touch, smell, sound, taste, and sight.

Example: Describing a Lake

Pre-writing using senses:

  • Touch: warm water, hot sand, heat
  • Smell: fresh air, fish, hot dogs, sun block
  • Sound: laughing, splashing, music
  • Taste: sand, lotion
  • Sight: the sun, sand, children, lifeguards, boats

Resulting Paragraph: Lake Harriet is a great place to swim and relax. In the summer, the water is warm and clean, and the beaches are large enough to accommodate groups of people seeking relief from a midsummer scorcher. The sweet scent of sun block wafts through the air from sunbathers. Children laugh and splash in the water, and nearby volleyball games stir passionate shouts. In the distance, sailboats catch the soft breezes that ripple the lake's surface. This is what summer is all about!

Techniques of describing a person

  1. Start with a general topic sentence that introduces the person.
  2. Focus on the most striking part of their appearance first.
  3. Use physical details that hint at the person’s personality.
  4. Use figurative language like similes and metaphors.

Exercise: Combining Sentences

Combine the following two sentences into one by listing the adjectives: "He is kind-hearted. He is very thoughtful and friendly to everyone."

"He is kind-hearted, very thoughtful, and friendly to everyone."

chapters.title: Narrative Paragraph
chapters.content:
Definition: A narrative paragraph tells a story using specific details in chronological (time) order.

Purpose: To show the reader the events that happened.

In academic writing, an incident is often used to illustrate a larger point. A narrative paragraph answers the 5-wh questions (what, when, where, who, why) and 1 h-question (how).

Use of Tenses

  • Simple Past: Use for a succession of events. "I got up, went to the kitchen, and opened the door."
  • Past Continuous: Use for an interrupted action. "Sharon was working in the garden when the telephone rang."
  • Past Perfect: Use for actions that were finished before another past action. "Janet didn't join us for dinner as she had already eaten."

Use of Transitional Devices

Start sentences with linking phrases like 'Then,', 'Next,', 'After that,', and 'Finally,' to connect sentences and show time relationships in your narrative writing.

Example: A Travel Nightmare

When I decided to travel across Europe with a backpack, I did not think I would meet the local police. My best friend and I were sitting in Frankfurt on a train bound for Paris when the nightmare began. A young man came to the window and asked me at what time the train leaves. It took us only ten seconds to open the window and answer him. When we turned away from the window and sat down on our seats, we noticed that our backpacks were missing. Quickly, we got off the train and went to the police station. They explained that it was a common way of stealing bags; one person distracts a passenger while another steals their valuables. That is how our nightmare came to a surprising end.

Exercise: Using Past Verbs and Prepositions

Complete the following sentences to form a paragraph. Use the past tense of the verb and the correct preposition.

Yesterday evening Jack _____ (get) home _____ (preposition) half past five. He immediately _____ (make) himself a cup _____ (preposition) coffee and _____ (sit down) to read a book. He _____ (read) the book _____ (preposition) half past seven. Then, he _____ (make) dinner and _____ (get ready) to go out with his friends. When his friends _____ (arrive), they _____ (decide) to go out to see a film. He _____ (stay out) until midnight with his friends. Finally, he _____ (fall) asleep _____ (preposition) about one o'clock.

Yesterday evening Jack got home at half past five. He immediately made himself a cup of coffee and sat down to read a book. He read the book until half past seven. Then, he made dinner and got ready to go out with his friends. When his friends arrived, they decided to go out to see a film. He stayed out until midnight with his friends. Finally, he fell asleep at about one o'clock.

chapters.title: Cause-Effect Paragraph
chapters.content:
Definition: A cause and effect paragraph shows the result or results that follow from an event (the cause or causes).

Purpose: To explain to the reader how one thing may affect another.

Cause-effect paragraphs can be structured in two main ways:

  • Focus on causes: The paragraph explains the reasons *why* something happened. The topic sentence introduces an effect, and the supporting sentences detail its causes.
  • Focus on effects: The paragraph explains *what happens* as a result of something. The topic sentence introduces a cause, and the supporting sentences detail its effects.

Useful Transitional Devices

  • For Cause: For, because, since, due to, for this reason, creates, leads to...
  • For Effect: So, as a consequence, as a result, consequently, therefore, thus, hence...

Example: Pollution and Human Life (Focus on Effects)

Pollution which is one of the biggest problems facing the world today has many effects on human life. First of all, pollution is bad for people's health. For example, smog, caused by car's exhaust fumes, can lead to lung diseases. Also, polluted food and water can cause cancer. Another effect of pollution is the destruction of human habitat. Thus, an oil spill can make an area uninhabitable. To sum up, pollution has many negative effects on the lives of humans.

chapters.title: Tense
chapters.content:
In grammar, tense is a category that expresses time reference. Tenses are usually manifested by the use of specific forms of verbs, particularly in their conjugation patterns.

Present Tense

Present tense has four different forms: Simple Present, Present Progressive (Continuous), Present Perfect, and Present Perfect Progressive.

Present Indefinite Tense/ Simple Present Tense

The present indefinite tense denotes a stative or habitual or eternally true action. It's used for actions that happen regularly (always, usually, every day), or are general facts.

Structure: Subject + base verb (+ s/es for third-person singular). Example: I know Samia. He understands it.

Present Progressive (Continuous) Tense

This is used to indicate an ongoing action at the present moment (now, at this moment, right now). It can also be used to demonstrate future time.

Structure: Subject + am/is/are + verb + ing. Example: I am going to the university. Sami is leaving for Bhutan tomorrow.

Present Perfect Tense

Used to indicate an action that occurred at an indefinite time in the past but has an effect on the present, or an action that began in the past and is still ongoing.

Structure: Subject + have/has + past participle. Example: Sami has read the book. He has lived in this apartment for 15 years.

Note: Already comes between have/has and the past participle; yet appears with a negative form at the end of the sentence.

Present Perfect Progressive (Continuous)

Used to indicate an action that began in the past and is still occurring in the present, emphasizing the duration of the action.

Structure: Subject + have/has + been + [verb + ing]. Example: Sami has been reading for 3 hours.

Exercise I: Present Simple and Progressive

Complete the sentences with the verbs in brackets.

  1. Look. He ______ to us. (listen)
  2. We ______ at a hotel this week. (stay)
  3. I ______ to bed early on Sundays. (go)
  4. My mum is at the shop. She ______ a new dress. (buy)
  5. Jill ______ a lot of money. (have)
  6. They usually ______ on Sunday. (leave)
  7. Please, stop! You ______ so fast! (drive)
  8. We ______ in Berlin each year. (meet)
  9. We ______ to discos on Fridays. (go)
  10. He normally ______ on time. (come)
  11. I can't hear you! I ______ a shower. (have)
  12. Sam ______ his homework at night. (do)

1. is listening, 2. are staying, 3. go, 4. is buying, 5. has, 6. leave, 7. are driving, 8. meet, 9. go, 10. comes, 11. am having, 12. does

Exercise III: Present Perfect Simple and Continuous

Use the words in brackets to complete these sentences.

  1. She ______ puddings all day. She's pretty tired. (make)
  2. How many puddings ______ she ______? (make)
  3. I ______ for my keys since we came home. Where are they? (look)
  4. I ______ for my keys several times. But I haven't found them. (look)

1. She has been making puddings all day.
2. How many puddings has she made?
3. I have been looking for my keys since we came home.
4. I have looked for my keys several times.

Past Tense

Past tense has four forms: Simple Past, Past Progressive, Past Perfect, and Past Perfect Progressive.

Past Indefinite Tense / Simple Past Tense

Used to indicate a finished or completed action that occurred at a specific point in time in the past.

Structure: Subject + verb in the past form. Example: Sami went to Mexico last year.

Past Progressive (Continuous) Tense

Used to demonstrate an action that was happening in the past for a period of time, often when it was interrupted by another action.

Structure: Subject + was/were + verb + ing. Example: Sami was sleeping yesterday at 6:30 AM. When I went out, Samia was shouting from behind.

Past Perfect Tense

Used to demonstrate an action that occurred before another action in the past. There are usually two completed actions in the sentence.

Structure: Subject + had + past participle form of the main verb. Example: Samia had completed the task before the teacher asked.

Past Perfect Progressive Tense

An extension of the past perfect tense, used to demonstrate an action which continued for a specific period but stopped before another action.

Structure: Subject + had + been + verb+ing. Example: Akram had been playing cricket for 18 years before he retired.

Exercise I: Past Simple and Continuous Mistakes

Find mistakes and correct them.

  1. I was doing my homework first and then I had a rest.
  2. My mum was often driving when she was younger.
  3. While daddy didn't look, Susan put his key in her pocket.
  4. I needed to talk to her. And at 10 I was calling her.
  5. I saw you with Jill at the cafe. You talked.

1. I did my homework... 2. Correct. 3. While daddy wasn't looking... 4. ...at 10 I called her. 5. You were talking. 6. Where did you study? 7. Correct. 8. I took her to Dover. 9. ...the sun shone. 10. Correct.

Future Tense

The future tense refers to a time later than now, and expresses facts or certainty.

Simple Future Tense (will)

Used to predict a future event, express a spontaneous decision, show willingness, or give an order.

Example: It will rain tomorrow. I'll pay for the tickets by credit card.

Will vs. Going To

  • Use GOING TO for actions you have already decided on (prior plans) or when there are definite signs something is going to happen (evidence).
  • Use WILL for rapid decisions made at the moment of speaking, or for predictions based on belief.

Future Continuous Tense

Refers to an unfinished action or event that will be in progress at a time later than now.

Structure: will + be + verb+ing. Example: This time next week I will be exploring the valley of Sajek.

Future Perfect Tense

Refers to a completed action in the future. We are projecting ourselves forward and looking back at an action that will be completed.

Structure: will + have + past participle. Example: By the time you read this, I will have left.

Future Perfect Continuous

Refers to events or actions that are currently unfinished but will be finished at some future time, emphasizing the duration.

Structure: will + have + been + verb+ing. Example: I will have been waiting here for three hours by six o'clock.

Exercise I: Future Simple or Continuous

Rewrite the underlined forms.

  1. Don't call me at 10 o'clock. I am going to fly to Spain.
  2. I suppose we're going to stay at a hotel next summer.
  3. Come to see me in the afternoon. I work in the garden.
  4. Do you think it is snowing at the weekend?
  5. Is the coat OK? - Yes, I am taking it.

1. will be flying, 2. we'll be staying, 3. will be working, 4. it'll be snowing, 5. I'll take, 6. we'll be skiing, 7. I'll move, 8. will be using

Exercise V: Mixed Future Tenses

Complete the passage with the correct form of future tense.

Sami’s family usually comes to stay with us for the new year, but this new year we are going to visit them instead. They live in Cox’s Bazar. I can hardly wait – I a) ______ (have) a fantastic time there. School holiday’s b) ______ (start) on Friday, and we are going to leave the following morning. At this time next week, I c) ______ (swim) in the sea. He’s an expert, and he d) ______ (practice) with me every day. By the last day of our visit... I hope by then I e) ______ (improve) enough to swim with them. Next year, I f) ______ (learn) scuba diving.

1. will have, 2. will start, 3. will be swimming, 4. am going to practice, 5. will have improved, 6. am going to learn

chapters.title: Subject-Verb Agreement
chapters.content:
Being able to find the right subject and verb will help you correct errors of subject-verb agreement. The basic rule is that a singular subject takes a singular verb, while a plural subject takes a plural verb.

Key Rules

Rule 1. A subject will come before a phrase beginning with 'of'. This is a key rule for understanding subjects. The word 'of' is the culprit in many, perhaps most, subject-verb mistakes.
Incorrect: A bouquet of yellow roses lend color...
Correct: A bouquet of yellow roses lends... (The subject is 'bouquet', not 'roses')

Rule 2. Two singular subjects connected by 'or', 'either/or', or 'neither/nor' require a singular verb.
Example: My aunt or my uncle is arriving by train today.

Rule 3. The verb in an 'or', 'either/or', or 'neither/nor' sentence agrees with the noun or pronoun closest to it.
Example: Neither the serving bowl nor the plates go on that shelf. (Plates is plural and closer to the verb)

Rule 4. As a general rule, use a plural verb with two or more subjects when they are connected by 'and'.
Example: A car and a bike are my means of transportation.

Rule 5a. Sometimes the subject is separated from the verb by words such as 'along with', 'as well as', 'besides', 'not', etc. These words are not part of the subject.
Example: The politician, along with the newsmen, is expected shortly.

Rule 6. In sentences beginning with 'here' or 'there', the true subject follows the verb.
Example: There are four hurdles to jump. (The subject is 'hurdles')

Rule 7. Use a singular verb with distances, periods of time, sums of money, etc., when considered as a unit.
Example: Five years is the maximum sentence for that offense.

Rule 9. The word 'were' replaces 'was' in sentences that express a wish or are contrary to fact (the subjunctive mood).
Example: If Joe were here, you'd be sorry.

Exercise I

Circle the correct verb in each of the sentences below.

  1. Your friend (talk-talks) too much.
  2. The man with the roses (look-looks) like your brother.
  3. The women in the pool (swim-swims) well.
  4. Bill (drive-drives) a cab.
  5. The football players (run-runs) five miles every day.

1. talks, 2. looks, 3. swim, 4. drives, 5. run, 6. lives, 7. cooks, 8. walk, 9. appears, 10. bounces

chapters.title: Sentence Fragments
chapters.content:
The Basics

A complete sentence has three components: a subject (the actor), a predicate (the verb or action), and a complete thought (it can stand alone and make sense).

Sentence Fragments

A sentence fragment is an incomplete sentence. Some fragments are incomplete because they lack either a subject or a verb, or both. The fragments that most students have trouble with, however, are dependent clauses—they have a subject and a verb, so they look like complete sentences, but they don’t express a complete thought.

Example of a fragment: Because his car was in the shop. (What did he do? The thought is incomplete.)

This is a fragment because it begins with a subordinator (subordinating conjunction) like 'Because', 'After', 'When', 'Since', or 'If'.

To fix a fragment, you need to attach the dependent clause to an independent clause.

Correct: Because his car was in the shop, John took the bus.

Exercise I

Indicate whether each part is a fragment (F) or sentence (S).

  1. Startled by the loud noise of the engine. I dropped the wrench and jumped out of the way.
  2. Sami was standing on the corner. Watching all the cars go by.
  3. Ridita gathered some dry twigs. And tried to start a fire for us.
  4. All of us waited at the door. To let the man in the wheelchair by.
  5. Written by a Black poet. Who had spent many years in the ghetto.

1. S, F | 2. S, F | 3. S, F | 4. S, F | 5. F, F | 6. S, S | 7. F, S | 8. S, S | 9. F, S | 10. S, S
